subject: Interviews from Venice
event:
Here's a video interview from my visit to the Food Truck on Friday:

<lj-embed id="161"/>

And another interview with me from the Venice streets can be found at:

http://www.hitfix.com/blogs/the-fien-print/posts/hitfix-interview-a-few-minutes-with-george-r-r-martin-at-the-game-of-thrones-food-truck

It was great to meet so many of my fans and readers in Venice.  And the venison and lemon cake were wonderful as well.

comments.article: I really like this video interview, it's very smile-y and doesn't really follow the usual questions :)
comments.subject: Great

comments.article: Great interview, you're looking good man! Married life must be treating you right!
Great interview. One of the first I've had a chance to see that wasn't little more than a soundbite.
LEMONCAKES is definitely a soundbite.

This was a wonderful interview basically encapsulating the essence of what makes the "A Song Of Ice And Fire" novels and now the upcoming HBO series "Game Of Thrones" so fascinating and interesting.

Well, sir, I have tried to do my best as a fan to support both the books and the series. My HBO (HBO Canada) subscription is up and running and I am now just counting down the remaining days until the premiere. From HBO I have already purchased two of the shows signature T-Shirts, the Lannister House stein or mug with their logo and "Hear Me Roar" (it is a lot heavier than I thought it will be, which is fine because its quality is good). I have also purchased the new editions of all four published novels, plus the HBO-tie-in edition with Ned on the cover, I also have this year's 2011 calendar and will surely purchase the 2012 edition. In addition I have also bought the first volume of "The Art Of A Song Of Ice And Fire", I have also ordered and waiting to receive the second volume of "The Art Of A Song Of Ice And Fire" which was published recently. The purchase of the "Game Of Thrones" DVD set of the first season is a given and I will be there to pick-it up once it comes out, and of course I am looking forward to the publication of "A Dance With Dragons".

This the only way I could think to thank you and all the people over at HBO for your great work and effort. My hope is that in whatever small and indirect way this will help the ASOIF novels become even more successful, respected and recognized, because you so richly deserve it. I also hope that HBO will be convinced that they have something viable and profitable on their hands and thus ensure a multi-season arch that will cover the entire saga.

Thank you once again for everything. Now I will sign-off for a while, actually until the show has aired in its entirety. As someone pointed out there is such a thing as information overload, trailers, behind the scenes, interviews, reviews etc.

I will be back around these hallowed grounds around July to see what has transpired in the land of ice and fire and see how it all has gone down. I will retreat and just simply enjoy the books and the show!

I wish everybody involved good luck, all the best! I hope this turns out to be HUGE?!!??!

Bye now sir...be well...until next time!
comments.subject: Winter is almost here!

comments.article: A few more interviews by sultry-eyed fan girls such as these and Parris will start packing the baseball bat...
Fantastic interview.  I've never watched you in video before and I think you're quite the interviewer.  Good job!

Great interview. I think it's pretty obvious those gals were fans of the show and they asked some interesting questions, (and of course the answers were good as well). Really looking forward to the show.

I was stuck working the Monsterpalooza show in Burbank that day... but my lovely friend Keri did get you to sign a menu for me. *smiles* Those lemoncakes WERE fantastic. And I have a nice big stack of those napkins now to use at our Epic Viewing Party. *grins*
Great interview!
nice to see an interview with george that isn't behind a table. and that woman on the left is gorgeous.
One week to go!!

Is it me or Mr Martin looks rejuvenated in this interview?? Great one!

Pau aka "Thorrgal"
Enjoyed this interview.  As others above have noted, it wasn't the same old standard questions.
Wow...interviewed by a couple of hotties....I really need to write a book, get it published, and get it picked up for a mini-series just to be interviewed by attractive women....if only!
That might be the most awkward interview I've seen you do.  Very cute to see you squirm a bit around hot fan-girls.

I've been writing on A Game of Thrones all semester in an Intro to Theory course, which has mostly involved me geeking out over the last chapter of the book.

You'd think I'd be sick of it by now, but I cannot wait to see that scene (presuming the last scene in the book will be the last shot of the series).
It will be. One of either Benioff or Weiss said it in an interview recently. Hopefully it'll be as awesome as in the book.

I know this is off-topic.

I have been eager to try my hand with some new fantasy while I wait for the Dance. I am embarrassingly ignorant about the genre -- all I can say is that I love Tolkie, Martin, and Jack Vance. I have heard some excellent things about Gene Wolfe. George or anyone else -- what do you think? Should I give Wolfe a try? And if so, where should I start?
comments.subject: While waiting for the Dance...

comments.article:
Gene Wolfe is a brilliant writer, one of the best we've ever had in this genre... but he is not an easy read. His work is full of layers, of hidden meanings, of puzzles and enigmas and things that only become clear on the second or third reading. There are great rewards to be found in Wolfe's work, yes, but the books do not yield up their treasures to every reader. You need to work at it.

Some readers love this. Some don't.

I'd start with the Book of the New Sun. For a fantasy fan, that's the one most likely to appeal.
comments.subject: Re: While waiting for the Dance...
Re: While waiting for the Dance...

comments.article: Patrick Rothfuss, Joe Abercrombie, Brandon Sanderson......Three authors who I greatly enjoy. Give some of there stuff a read!
comments.subject: Re: While waiting for the Dance...

comments.article:
It was such a great surprise to see you at the head of the line. I know it must have been exhausting chatting with the hundreds of us fans but you held up well. Thanks for the food!

And I promise, my friend and I won't stalk you to Dublin when you head there for season 2.

The food truck marketing was one of my very favorite parts of the lead up to the show premiere. I think it's great you got to try some!

It's also inspired us to start a blog in which we attempt to cook and bake our way through the delicious foods in your books. Our mouths always watered when reading about the feasts, or even about the more simple fare up on The Wall, and our experiment so far has yielded tasty results. We guestimate there will be around 170 dishes, but that's before the next book comes out! :)

Thank you so much for all your hard work and imagination. You've inspired many of us to also take up a creative mantle and try fun new things! YOU ROCK!

(Shameless plug!)
http://www.innatthecrossroads.wordpress.com
comments.subject: Love the Food!

comments.article: Skip the seagull when you get to it.  I'm told seagulls are not really very... ah... edible.
comments.subject: Re: Love the Food!

comments.article:
Hey George,
I just wanted to say that good writing and acting overcomes any sort of monetary deficit associated with a tv series. I leave so many "big budget" movies with a distinct sense of dissatisfaction because the effects are amazing and the acting and story seem to be forgotten in the process. So again we're just excited to see excellent books get turned into a tv series.
Thanks
comments.subject: Lord of the Rings
